Send a command {\ttfamily Antiflickering\+Set\+Mode} in feature {\ttfamily A\+R\+Drone3} Set the antiflickering mode. If auto, the drone will detect when flickers appears on the video and trigger the antiflickering. In this case, this electric frequency it will use will be the one specified in the event \href{#1-29-0}{\tt Electric\+Frequency}. Forcing the antiflickering (Fixed\+Fifty\+Hertz or Fixed\+Fifty\+Hertz) can reduce luminosity of the video.

Send a command {\ttfamily Media\+Record\+Picture\+V2} in feature {\ttfamily A\+R\+Drone3} Take a picture. The type of picture taken is related to the picture setting. You can set the picture format by sending the command \href{#1-19-0}{\tt Set\+Picture\+Format}. You can also get the current picture format with \href{#1-20-0}{\tt Picture\+Format}. Please note that the time required to take the picture is highly related to this format. 

You can check if the picture taking is available with \href{#1-8-2}{\tt Picture\+State}. Also, please note that if your picture format is different from snapshot, picture taking will stop video recording (it will restart after that the picture has been taken).

Send a command {\ttfamily Media\+Record\+Video\+V2} in feature {\ttfamily A\+R\+Drone3} Record a video (or start timelapse). You can check if the video recording is available with \href{#1-8-3}{\tt Video\+State}. This command can start a video (obvious huh?), but also a timelapse if the timelapse mode is set. You can check if the timelapse mode is set with the event \href{#1-20-4}{\tt Timelapse\+Mode}. Also, please note that if your picture format is different from snapshot, picture taking will stop video recording (it will restart after the picture has been taken).

Send a command {\ttfamily Piloting\+Move\+To} in feature {\ttfamily A\+R\+Drone3} Move the drone to a specified location. If a new command move\+To is sent, the drone will immediatly cancel the previous one. If a \href{#1-0-11}{\tt Cancel\+Move\+To} command is sent, the move\+To is stopped. During the move\+To, all pitch, roll and gaz values of the piloting command will be ignored by the drone. However, the yaw value can be used.

\hline

\hline
{\em orientation\+\_\+mode} & Orientation mode of the move to \\
\hline
{\em heading} & Heading (relative to the North in degrees). This value is only used if the orientation mode is H\+E\+A\+D\+I\+N\+G\+\_\+\+S\+T\+A\+RT or H\+E\+A\+D\+I\+N\+G\+\_\+\+D\+U\+R\+I\+NG return executing error \\
\hline

Send a command {\ttfamily Piloting\+P\+C\+MD} in feature {\ttfamily A\+R\+Drone3} Move the drone. The lib\+A\+R\+Controller is sending the command each 50ms. 

{\bfseries Please note that you should call set\+Piloting\+P\+C\+MD and not send\+Piloting\+P\+C\+MD because the lib\+A\+R\+Controller is handling the periodicity and the buffer on which it is sent.} 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em feature} & feature owning the commands \\
\hline
{\em flag} & Boolean flag\+: 1 if the roll and pitch values should be taken in consideration. 0 otherwise \\
\hline
{\em roll} & Roll angle as signed percentage. On copters\+: Roll angle expressed as signed percentage of the max pitch/roll setting, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]} -\/100 corresponds to a roll angle of max pitch/roll to the left (drone will fly left) 100 corresponds to a roll angle of max pitch/roll to the right (drone will fly right) This value may be clamped if necessary, in order to respect the maximum supported physical tilt of the copter. On fixed wings\+: Roll angle expressed as signed percentage of the physical max roll of the wing, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]} Negative value makes the plane fly to the left Positive value makes the plane fly to the right \\
\hline
{\em pitch} & Pitch angle as signed percentage. On copters\+: Expressed as signed percentage of the max pitch/roll setting, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]} -\/100 corresponds to a pitch angle of max pitch/roll towards sky (drone will fly backward) 100 corresponds to a pitch angle of max pitch/roll towards ground (drone will fly forward) This value may be clamped if necessary, in order to respect the maximum supported physical tilt of the copter. On fixed wings\+: Expressed as signed percentage of the physical max pitch of the wing, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]} Negative value makes the plane fly in direction of the sky Positive value makes the plane fly in direction of the ground \\
\hline
{\em yaw} & Yaw rotation speed as signed percentage. On copters\+: Expressed as signed percentage of the max yaw rotation speed setting, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]}. -\/100 corresponds to a counter-\/clockwise rotation of max yaw rotation speed 100 corresponds to a clockwise rotation of max yaw rotation speed This value may be clamped if necessary, in order to respect the maximum supported physical tilt of the copter. On fixed wings\+: Giving more than a fixed value (75\% for the moment) triggers a circle. Positive value will trigger a clockwise circling Negative value will trigger a counter-\/clockwise circling \\
\hline
{\em gaz} & Throttle as signed percentage. On copters\+: Expressed as signed percentage of the max vertical speed setting, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]} -\/100 corresponds to a max vertical speed towards ground 100 corresponds to a max vertical speed towards sky This value may be clamped if necessary, in order to respect the maximum supported physical tilt of the copter. During the landing phase, putting some positive gaz will cancel the land. On fixed wings\+: Expressed as signed percentage of the physical max throttle, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]} Negative value makes the plane fly slower Positive value makes the plane fly faster \\
\hline
{\em timestamp\+And\+Seq\+Num} & Command timestamp in milliseconds (low 24 bits) + command sequence number (high 8 bits) \mbox{[}0;255\mbox{]}. return executing error \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

Send a command {\ttfamily Piloting\+Settings\+No\+Fly\+Over\+Max\+Distance} in feature {\ttfamily A\+R\+Drone3} Enable geofence. If geofence is enabled, the drone won\textquotesingle{}t fly over the given max distance. You can get the max distance from the event \href{#1-6-3}{\tt Max\+Distance}. For copters\+: the distance is computed from the controller position, if this position is not known, it will use the take off. For fixed wings\+: the distance is computed from the take off position.

{\em feature} & feature owning the commands \\
\hline
{\em flag} & Boolean flag\+: 1 if the roll and pitch values should be taken in consideration. 0 otherwise \\
\hline
{\em roll} & Roll angle as signed percentage. On copters\+: Roll angle expressed as signed percentage of the max pitch/roll setting, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]} -\/100 corresponds to a roll angle of max pitch/roll to the left (drone will fly left) 100 corresponds to a roll angle of max pitch/roll to the right (drone will fly right) This value may be clamped if necessary, in order to respect the maximum supported physical tilt of the copter. On fixed wings\+: Roll angle expressed as signed percentage of the physical max roll of the wing, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]} Negative value makes the plane fly to the left Positive value makes the plane fly to the right \\
\hline
{\em pitch} & Pitch angle as signed percentage. On copters\+: Expressed as signed percentage of the max pitch/roll setting, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]} -\/100 corresponds to a pitch angle of max pitch/roll towards sky (drone will fly backward) 100 corresponds to a pitch angle of max pitch/roll towards ground (drone will fly forward) This value may be clamped if necessary, in order to respect the maximum supported physical tilt of the copter. On fixed wings\+: Expressed as signed percentage of the physical max pitch of the wing, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]} Negative value makes the plane fly in direction of the sky Positive value makes the plane fly in direction of the ground \\
\hline
{\em yaw} & Yaw rotation speed as signed percentage. On copters\+: Expressed as signed percentage of the max yaw rotation speed setting, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]}. -\/100 corresponds to a counter-\/clockwise rotation of max yaw rotation speed 100 corresponds to a clockwise rotation of max yaw rotation speed This value may be clamped if necessary, in order to respect the maximum supported physical tilt of the copter. On fixed wings\+: Giving more than a fixed value (75\% for the moment) triggers a circle. Positive value will trigger a clockwise circling Negative value will trigger a counter-\/clockwise circling \\
\hline
{\em gaz} & Throttle as signed percentage. On copters\+: Expressed as signed percentage of the max vertical speed setting, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]} -\/100 corresponds to a max vertical speed towards ground 100 corresponds to a max vertical speed towards sky This value may be clamped if necessary, in order to respect the maximum supported physical tilt of the copter. During the landing phase, putting some positive gaz will cancel the land. On fixed wings\+: Expressed as signed percentage of the physical max throttle, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]} Negative value makes the plane fly slower Positive value makes the plane fly faster \\
\hline
{\em timestamp\+And\+Seq\+Num} & Command timestamp in milliseconds (low 24 bits) + command sequence number (high 8 bits) \mbox{[}0;255\mbox{]}. return executing error \\
\hline

\hline

\end{DoxyParams}

Send a command {\ttfamily Axis\+Filters\+Set\+Axis\+Filter} in feature {\ttfamily Sky\+Controller} A filter modifies the response curve of an axis. As the preset filters list is empty, all filters are to be sent using the builder syntax. 

The builder syntax supports two types of filters\+: Multilinear and Exponential.

Multilinear filters create response curves made of multiple linear segments\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The default filter (A\+R\+MF;) is purely linear and create a single segment from the two implicit {\ttfamily \mbox{[}-\/1; -\/1\mbox{]}} and {\ttfamily \mbox{[}1; 1\mbox{]}} points.
\item Additionnal points can be added to the filter with the following syntax\+: {\ttfamily A\+R\+MF;x1$>$y1;...;xN$>$yN;}, where all numbers are floating point numbers in range {\ttfamily \mbox{[}-\/1; 1\mbox{]}}.
\item Additionnal points {\bfseries must} respect the following constraints \+: {\ttfamily x(\+N)$>$x(N-\/1)} and {\ttfamily y(\+N)$>$=y(N-\/1)}.
\end{DoxyItemize}

Exponential filters\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The syntax is {\ttfamily A\+R\+XF;C\+Px;C\+Py;}, where C\+Px and C\+Py are floating point numbers in range {\ttfamily \mbox{[}0; 1\mbox{]}}.
\item Best results are achieved when {\ttfamily C\+Px + C\+Py == 1} and {\ttfamily C\+Px $>$ C\+Py}.
\item If the control point is on the diagonal (i.\+e. {\ttfamily C\+Px == C\+Py}), then the resulting filter will be linear. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em feature} & feature owning the commands \\
\hline
{\em axis\+\_\+id} & The axiscode to filter \\
\hline
{\em filter\+\_\+uid\+\_\+or\+\_\+builder} & The mapping preset to associate with the axis (Or a string to build a new one) return executing error \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

Send a command {\ttfamily Co\+Piloting\+Set\+Piloting\+Source} in feature {\ttfamily Sky\+Controller} Change who is piloting the drone. By default, the Sky\+Controller is the source of piloting commands, and any connected application (i.\+e. Free\+Flight) can not send \href{#1-0-2}{\tt piloting commands} commands directly to the drone. When the piloting source is set to Controller, the Sky\+Controller will forward the controller commands to the drone, and won\textquotesingle{}t send any commands itself. The piloting source is automatically reset to Sky\+Controller when the controller is disconnected.
